title: Fifth Star  tells story of Ohio fight for women right to vote
body_text:
‘Fifth Star’ tells story of Ohio’s fight for women’s right to vote | Book Talk
Before Ohio was even 30 years old, its women were advocating for the civil rights of others. The Indian Removal Act of 1830 stole land from Native Americans and displaced them, and 62 Steubenville women filed a petition voicing their objections to the injustice. In “The Fifth Star: Ohio’s Fight for Women’s Right to Vote,” Jamie C. Capuzza studies more than suffrage.
The landmark 1848 Seneca Falls Convention, at which Frederick Douglass, Elizabeth Cady Stanton and Lucretia Mott spoke, took on temperance and the rights of women to own property and hold employment. Others followed, notably the larger event in 1850 in Salem and at Akron in 1851, at which Sojourner Truth famously gave her “Ain’t I a Woman” speech.
Capuzza follows through with every petition, ballot, conference and campaign. This stirring and necessary book ends with the “fifth star” — Ohio as the fifth state to pass the 19th Amendment.
“The Fifth Star” (344 pages, softcover) costs $28 from Kent State University Press. Capuzza is a professor in the Department of Literature and Communication Arts and directs the Gender and Sexuality Studies program at the University of Mount Union.
‘The Note Who Faced the Music’
Half Note feels underappreciated. On the music staff, Eighth Note gets to jump around, Whole Note “can fill a whole measure.” In “The Note Who Faced the Music,” a storybook by North Canton children’s author Lindsay Bonilla, Half Note learns that every note is needed to make a melody.
Though the other notes offer some consolation, Half Note decides to walk out, leaving Composer short-staffed. He tries to make do with the other notes but it’s terrible. Half Note hears the awful racket and knows that a missing note leaves everything flat.
“The Note Who Faced the Music” (32 pages, hardcover), recommended for readers ages 4-8, costs $18.99 from Page Publishing. Lindsay Bonilla also is the author of the delightful inclusivity-themed “Polar Bear Island.” The illustrations are by New Hampshire artist Mark Hoffman.
‘Coach Geoge Allen’
In his preface to “Coach George Allen: A Football Life,” Tallmadge writer Lee Elder says that the Pro Football Hall of Fame inductee was the “first modern NFL coach.” His book, which he calls the first full-length biography of the Michigan native, covers Allen’s childhood, during which he had to leave school occasionally to support his family while his father suffered from ill health.
Allen coached at small colleges in Iowa and California before moving up to the Rams, then to the Bears and back to the Rams. He followed those tenures with a stint at the Washington Redskins (now Commanders) and then back to the Rams. “Why was Allen fired four times by the Rams?” Elder asks.
Elder points to Allen’s innovative use of game films and his determination to acquire the most advanced technology for his teams, and adopted an early form of personality testing to determine his communication style. Though accounts vary, Elder cites Hall of Fame coach Marvin Levy, who gives credit to Allen for coining the term “sack.”
“Coach George Allen” (268 pages, softcover) costs $35 from McFarland Books. Elder is the executive director of the Professional Football Researchers Association and worked as a publicist for Goodyear Racing.
